Netlib.  Netlib , a collection of  mathematical software, papers, and databases, is operated by ORNL and the University of Tennessee, Knoxville.      ATLAS    ATLAS (Automatically Tuned Linear Algebra Software) is an approach for  the automatic generation and optimization of numerical software.   CUMULVS   CUMULVS  (Collaborative User Migration, User Library for Visualization and Steering) is a software infrastructure for the development of collaborative environments.     Electronic notebook     The electronic notebook is an important tool  for scientists and engineers doing remote experimentation and collaboration.      OSCAR   OSCAR (Open Source Cluster Application Resources)  is a snapshot of the best-known methods for building, programming, and using clusters. It consists of a fully integrated and easy-to-install software bundle designed for high-performance cluster computing. Everything needed to install, build, maintain, and use a modestly sized Linux cluster is included in the suite, making it unnecessary to download or even install any individual software packages on your cluster.      PVM   PVM (Parallel Virtual Machine) is a software package that permits  a heterogeneous collection of Unix computers hooked together by a network to be used as a single  large parallel computer.  The software is very portable. The  source, which is available free through netlib, has been compiled on everything from laptops to Crays.    ScaLAPACK   The ScaLAPACK project is a collaborative effort involving several  institutions and comprises four components: dense and band matrix software, large sparse eigenvalue software, sparse direct systems software,  and preconditioners for large sparse iterative solvers.                                                              inside-csm   |   employee info   |    computing info   |    development   |    who, what, where?   |    ornl connections   |    news/results   ornl   |    directorate   |    cse   |    csm   |    nct   |    ccs   |    disclaimer   |    search                                                 URL  http://www.csm.ornl.gov/software.html  Updated:  Tuesday, 09-Jul-2002 15:38:55 EDT   webmaster

Our collaborations with other scientists cut across many areas, including the physical sciences, computational sciences, environmental sciences, biological sciences, epidemiology, engineering, and chemistry. New Technology Analysis          Oak Ridge National Laboratory         http://www.ornl.gov    Collaborative Management Environment           The Collaborative Management Environment (CME) creates an  environment for financially managing and analyzing research  funding at the U.S. Department of Energy. CME addresses challenges  in distributed data and web searches for information integration at  a low cost and with minimal impact for the national laboratories  involved. CME provides complete and consistent data to DOE while  allowing gains in efficiency by an order of magnitude for the process  of proposal submissions. It also provides a safe and trusted environment  for researchers and program managers. CME uses the Extensible Mark-up  Language (XML) and its own information model for schema migration.   CME provides for efficient management of very large and heterogeneous  information by integrating disperse collections of heterogeneous data.  The project began in 1996 and has been fully funded since then by the  Department of Energy.     CME is a project of the Collaborative Technologies Research Center  (CTRC) which was established in October 1996 with the support of the  Mathematical, Information, and Computational Sciences (MICS) Division  of the Office of Advanced Scientific Computing Research (OASCR) of the  US Department of Energy (DOE).  Its mission is to develop advanced  collaborative technologies and other related technologies to support  interdisciplinary researchers and decision makers in areas of importance  to DOE, including scientific simulation and modeling, enterprise  management, remote instrumentation, disaster management, and engineering  design and management.    Disclaimers                                                                                                     Probe - Storage and Networking Research Facility    The Oak Ridge National Laboratory's Computer Science and Mathematics Division has established a research facility, titled "Probe", in which challenging storage- or network-related studies can be performed. The National Energy Research Scientific Computing Center (NERSC) is a partner in Probe, providing the second node in a wide-area distributed-storage testbed.    Probe supports research into new network protocols, storage configuration and database technologies such as data mining, distributed databases and high-dimensional database accesses. Probe also tests new equipment (servers, network interfaces and switches, storage devices), new protocols (scheduled transfer, for instance), and software (the High Performance Storage System, database products, etcetera).    In particular, Probe is involved in several SciDAC projects including the Scientific Data Management Integrated Software Infrastructure Center, the DOE Science Grid, Earth Systems Grid II and the Climate and Terascale Supernova Initiative projects, as well as working with Logistical Networking, a part of the National Collaboratories and Networking project.     For specific information on Probe's current resources, follow these   ORNL  and   NERSC   links.    Check out descriptions of  Active  and   Completed   Probe projects.   A variety of investigators may be able to use Probe; please see our  approval process  for more information.  If you would like to make use of Probe, you must fill out the   online request form .   Additional descriptive information is available at  Probe slides  and  press releases , and in  Probe - A Distributed Storage Testbed  (pdf).  Also, visit the page describing our  SC2001 activities .    Also please visit  Probe Project Status  which describes the accomplishments and ongoing work after the first year of Probe operation (second-year update is being written).    Disclaimers                                                                                                       Joint Institute for Computational Sciences   JICS : Objectives     The specific goals of the Joint Institute are to:         develop funding from public and private sector sources  for collaborative research and development projects;    focus collaborative research on a scientific agenda that  optimizes the contributions from areas of strength between  the participating institutions;     provide help and advice to the State of Tennessee, other  regional organizations, and the nation;     offer a unified focus for unique institutional R&D resources  of value to private industry;     establish new research facilities to house researchers from the  participating institutions working on Institute projects, and to formulate  a strategy for securing the funding required for developing such  research space;     formulate plans and secure resources to ensure that the Joint  Institute facilities include modern research equipment and  instrumentation suitable to support cutting edge research, including the      idea of a shared resources where applicable;     create collaborating scientist (joint appointments) positions between the member institutions for      new or current employees in the computational science disciplines (there are several joint faculty      positions planned under the UT-Battelle contract);    offer high quality education, training and on-the-job experience  for undergraduates, graduates, and continuing education for scientists  and  others through programs such as the DOE Computational Sciences  Graduate Fellowship;    promote the establishment of  a Graduate Program in  computational science between ORNL      and participating institutions;     offer a focal point for highlighting the work of, developing new  initiatives for, and bringing together researchers from the several  ongoing centers at ORNL and participating institutions that have  significant capabilities and  resources in the computational sciences.        A phased approach to developing projects under the Joint Institute  umbrella will be implemented. The initial focus is on  existing areas of emphasis for development of research programs between  the ORNL and Computational Sciences Directorate and participating  institutions.
